title: Technology:  CBS News Chief Nears Deal for a New Role  ----  By Joe Flint
text:
CBS News President Susan Zirinsky is nearing a deal to step down after just two years in the role and sign a wide-ranging production partnership with parent company ViacomCBS Inc., according to people familiar with the matter.

A search for a successor to Ms. Zirinsky has been continuing for several months but a candidate has yet to be named. It is expected that she will remain as head of CBS News until then, the people said.

Ms. Zirinksy and a CBS News spokeswoman declined to comment.

Ms. Zirinsky has been with CBS News for nearly 40 years, and her first love has always been being a hands-on news producer. As head of CBS News, much of her time is spent managing talent and dealing with corporate bureaucracy, and less with actual newsgathering.

The new production deal would allow her to return to her roots and create content not only for CBS News and its various shows and platforms but also the new ViacomCBS streaming service Paramount+, a person with knowledge of the pact said.

Although Ms. Zirinsky has been in the job for only two years, speculation about her desire to return to producing has been percolating for several months. When she took the job to head CBS News, she retained her title of senior executive producer. Last November, Business Insider reported that Ms. Zirinksy was itching to return to her roots.

During Ms. Zirinsky's two years at the helm, ratings for the CBS News morning and evening shows continued to decline and still trail the morning and nightly news shows on ABC and NBC.

But both CBS shows have somewhat narrowed the ratings gap with their competitors, which are also losing viewers.

Ms. Zirinksy also oversaw the negotiation of a new contract for popular "CBS This Morning" anchor Gayle King and installed production chiefs at most of the unit's programs.

Ms. Zirinsky's big bet at "CBS Evening News" was putting morning show co-host Norah O'Donnell in the anchor seat of the evening show and moving the show to Washington, D.C., from New York. The ratings race among the three traditional network nightly news shows has tightened as well in viewers and demographics, although all three lost viewers in the first quarter of 2021 compared with the same period a year ago.

Ms. Zirinsky isn't the only expected major executive departure at CBS News. One of her top deputies, Kim Godwin, is expected to succeed James Goldston, who resigned as president of Walt Disney Co.'s ABC News earlier this year, according to people familiar with that situation. An announcement about Ms. Godwin's appointment could come as early as this weekend, one of the people said.

An ABC spokeswoman declined to comment, and Ms. Godwin couldn't be reached for comment. NBC News was first to report on Ms. Godwin being Mr. Goldston's likely successor.
